justification: The authors note that research on motivated control often relies on 'tasks which … involve control processes that have been normatively motivated and empirically well-characterized (e.g., Stroop, flanker, task-switching)', indicating Stroop is used to measure cognitive control.
In the same clause, the Flanker task is listed alongside Stroop as a paradigm used to investigate and therefore measure control processes.
The sentence also includes task-switching paradigms as examples of tasks employed when studying motivated control, implying they serve as measures of cognitive control.
